unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, I've been thinking a lot about gym culture lately, especially in cities like Mumbai and Bangalore. It's exploded, right? Gone are the days when "working out" meant a jog around Shivaji Park. Now it's all about boutique fitness studios, HIIT classes, and protein shakes.
normalised: Hey everyone! So, I've been thinking a lot about gym culture lately, especially in cities like Mumbai and Bangalore. It's exploded, right? Gone are the days when "working out" meant a jog around Shivaji Park. Now it's all about boutique fitness studios, H I I T classes, and protein shakes.

unnormalised: I remember when I first joined a gym back in college (BITS Pilani days!). It was a tiny, cramped room maybe 200 sq ft, with basic weights. Now, these urban gyms are sprawling, air-conditioned palaces! You've got everything from crossfit rigs to dedicated yoga rooms. Even Dr. Sharma from next door is lifting weights now!
normalised: I remember when I first joined a gym back in college (B I T S Pilani days!). It was a tiny, cramped room maybe two hundred square feet, with basic weights. Now, these urban gyms are sprawling, air-conditioned palaces! You've got everything from crossfit rigs to dedicated yoga rooms. Even Doctor Sharma from next door is lifting weights now!

unnormalised: What's driving this? I think a big part of it is social media. Everyone's posting their workouts and progress pics. Peer pressure, perhaps? But also, there's a growing awareness of health and wellness, which is fantastic. People are willing to spend Rs. 5000+ a month for a good gym membership.
normalised: What's driving this? I think a big part of it is social media. Everyone's posting their workouts and progress pics. Peer pressure, perhaps? But also, there's a growing awareness of health and wellness, which is fantastic. People are willing to spend rupee five thousand plus a month for a good gym membership.

unnormalised: But sometimes I wonder, has it become a bit too much? Is it all about aesthetics now? Are we forgetting the "wellness" part in our quest for six-pack abs? I saw Rahul (my cousin) doing 20 km runs preparing for a marathon and felt inspired.
normalised: But sometimes I wonder, has it become a bit too much? Is it all about aesthetics now? Are we forgetting the "wellness" part in our quest for six-pack abs? I saw Rahul (my cousin) doing twenty kilometer runs preparing for a marathon and felt inspired.

unnormalised: What are your thoughts on urban gym culture? What are the pros and cons? Share your experiences! I'm curious to hear what everyone thinks. Let's discuss!
normalised: What are your thoughts on urban gym culture? What are the pros and cons? Share your experiences! I'm curious to hear what everyone thinks. Let's discuss!
